dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is unbelievable - look at this. There's no city like this in the world. There never was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's become so touristy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's just the awful era we live in but can you just imagine what this was like before - but even with all the fast food joints and the traffic - god, you just can't imagine what it was like years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you like cities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really do - I love cities - I love big cities with all the crowds and all the action. (Having seen a panoramic view of let us say the Champs El we embark on a montage of the city. The comments offered above and following are an approximation of what the acto feel.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at these places - the streets - the boulevards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You act like you've never been here before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get here often enough is the problem. Every once in a while for a few days is nothing - my biggest regret is that I didn't settle here the first time I came. I should have gone with my instincts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I admit it's pretty but so are so many other places I've visited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'd have stayed the first time I came by now I'd be a Parisian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3 (Pause here for third dialogue exchange)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking of a painting by Pisarro I've seen of Paris in the rain. Can you picture how drop dead gorgeous this city is in the rain? Imagine this town in the twenties - Paris in the twenties - in the rain - the artists and writers - I was born too late. Why did God deliver me into the world in the 1970's and in Pasadena yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does every city have to be in the rain? What's wonderful about getting wet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's romantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's annoying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or Paris when it's just getting dark - the lights go on - or at night - it's great at night - or no, sunset on the Champs Elysees -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you ever think of us moving here after we're married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god, no. I could never live out of the United States. And if I could it would be someplace totally different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Hawaii.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawaii is America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes but it's - Hawaiian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had stayed here and written novels and not gotten into grinding out movie scripts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, and becoming rich and successful. Tell me the sad story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is where all the artists came to live, to work - the writers, the painters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was ninety years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, I'd drop the house in Beverly Hills, the pool, everything - in a heartbeat. Look - this is where Monet lived and painted - we're thirty minutes from town. Imagine the two of us settling here. If my book turns out we could do it - you could just as easily make jewelry here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in love with a fantasy. Now we CUT AROUND and see Gil and Inez live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in love with you. (kiss)

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. HOTEL LOBBY
dialogues.text: 6 Gil and Inez enter lobby of hotel they are all at. In the lobby they are awaited by her parents, JOHN and HELEN BLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are our sight-seers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I never see another charming boulevard or bistro -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could easily see myself as a Parisien - strolling the Left Bank - a baguette under my arm - finishing my novel - at a table at the Cafe Flore. A Moveable Feast - Hemingway called it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this traffic nothing moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well yes it was different then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we continue this talk of moveable feasts at Grand Vefour because I'm starved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Americans eat dinner so early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm proud of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifting wine glass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A toast to John's new business venture here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'll be perfectly frank - I'm excited over this corporate merger between our people and the French company but otherwise I'm not a big Francophile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John hates their politics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've certainly been no friend to the united States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amiably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't say they weren't right in not backing Bush's moronic war in Iraq.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please let's not get into that discussion yet again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing wrong with your father and I disagreeing. That's what democracy is. Your father defends the right wing of the Republican party and I happen to think they represent sub-mental Neanderthals. But we respect each other's views - am I right? (this last directed at John gets no enthusiasm but a cold look from him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we discuss the wedding plans? Your father's used his good offices with the opera to get some of the singers to attend and sing. I thought Puccini would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that great Gil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just no Wagner. When she walks down the aisle not The Ride of the Valkyries. Hey look, I just want to say that I am politically bipartisan in that, in my view, to be a politician of any party one must of necessity be a whore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil. Just then another young couple pass the table and recogni Inez. PAUL and CAROL BATES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul! Carol- (ad-lib introductions)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Carol Bates - Mom, Dad, you know Gil - you didn't mention you'd be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was sudden. Paul got invited to lecture at the Sorbonne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - how terrific. Dad's here on business and we free-loaded along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's great.   We can spend some time together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't we have a lot of commitments?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing tomorrow?    We're driving to Versailles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dying to see Versailles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't we have something tomorrow? We were going to have lunch at the Brasserie Lipp. My old professor once actually saw James Joyce there. He said Joyce was eating sauerkraut and frankfurters. (silent pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the end of the story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is actually -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd love to go with you guys. Versailles is beautiful - I have to see it Gil - it's perfect for you with your obsession with "les temps perdus" В·

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's such a lovely treat running into you here. A demain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they do their nocturnal ablutions)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you're not going to be as anti-social tomorrow when we go to Versailles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was I anti-social?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was so clear you didn't want to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well they're your friends and I can't say I'm as taken with him as you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's brilliant. I used to have such a crush on him at college. And Carol's very bright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find him a pseudo-intellectual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hardly think the Sorbo nne would have him lecturing if he's a pseudo- intellectual. You should give him your novel to read. I'm sure he'd be able to critique your writing and show you why you're having so much trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having trouble because I'm a Hollywood hack who never gave actual literature a real shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (said with her usual seductiveness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil, promise me if this book doesn't come off you'll give up beating your brains out and get back to what you do best.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: 8 INEZ (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The studios adore you - you're in demand - I don't think you want to trade everything just to struggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9 Next day. The two couples are there and Paul waxes pedantically as they tour the grounds or inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe Louis moved his court here in about 1682 - originally this was all swamp land - in fact, if I'm not mistaken, in old French the word Versailles means something like "terrain where the weeds have been pulled". The main structure is French classical style at its height - the work, I believe of Louis Le Vau, I think Mansart and Charles LeBrun I believe В·В·В·

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I could get used to a summer home like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too except, remember, in those days they only had baths and I'm definitely a shower man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you two planning to live after the wedding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking in Malibu.   We love where you live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep trying to talk her into a little attic with a skylight in Paris -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La Boheme.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that's missing is tuberculosis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't even know if he can write a novel. So far your track record's - you know - whereas, everyone likes your movies -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes movie scripts are easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them about the lead character in the book you're working on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like to discuss my work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the plot, just the lead character. He works in a nostalgia shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a nostalgia shop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not one of those stores that sells Shirley Temple dolls and old radios? I never know who buys that stuff - who'd want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People who live in the past. Who think their lives would have been happier if they lived in an earlier time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just what era would you have preferred to live in, Miniver Cheevy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing Gil)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris in the twenties - in the rain - when the rain wasn't acid rain. 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. And no global warming, no TV or suicide bombing, nuclear weapons, drug cartels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual menu of cliched horror stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nostalgia is denial.   Denial of the painful present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a romantic. Gil would be just fine living in a perpetual state of denial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name for this fallacy is called, Golden Age thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The erroneous notion that a different time period was better than the one, one's living in. It's a flaw in the romantic imagination of those who find coping with the present too difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's definitely the nicest ring we've seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love a diamond wedding band. The way it sparkled they'll see it in the last row when he puts it on my finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is going to be such an event, Inez. I only wish -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting her off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to keep going over it, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, he's your choice.   What can I say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil's smart and successful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yet he talks of g1.v1.ng it up and moving here. That frightens me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world is full of people who dream of writing the great American novel. Let me handle him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're father thinks you're comfortable with Gil because you can control him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He likes to please me - is that so terrible? Oh gosh - I have to go - Paul arranged a private tour of the Rodin Museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 Paul, Carol, Gil and Inez getting guided tour.   Guide sp French and mostly English - as she feels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is, of course, Rodin's most famous statue. A cast of this work was placed next to his tomb. Rodin wished for it to serve as his headstone and epitaph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be in Meudon. He died of the flu if I'm not mistaken - 1917 I believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly correct. You know your art history, monsieur. The design -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting her off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Thinker is so powerful because he thinks not just with his brain - he thinks with every limb and muscle - you feel the concentration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gil)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's so knowledgeable, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So much of Rodin's work was influenced by his wife, Camille.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she was an influence - though Camille was not the wife but his mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camille?      No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.      Rose was the wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never married Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, in the last year of their lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you arguing with the guide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, non, non, je suis certaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid she's right. I just read the recent two volume biography of Rodin - Rose was definitely the wife, Camille the mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You read that? Where did you read that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did - no question.    Camille- Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget, Dad invited you to join us at a wine tasting tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be so fun. Paul's an expert on French wines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking with Gil) When did you read the biography of Rodin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Why would I read a biography of Rodin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 Inez already a little high.       Her parents having fun. also feeling it by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tasting) I can't tell the difference. They're both delicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy Inez.     Those little sips add up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should talk, John - especially for someone who once advocated the boycott of french wines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll always take a California wine but the Napa Valley is six thousand miles away. They laugh and drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gil)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which do you prefer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To me they're all great.   What the hell do I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I've ever seen your cheeks so red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pheromones, it's your pheromones. Paul and Carol have ambled over, having heard Gil's last amorous remark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah yes - sex and alcohol - It fuels the desire but kills the performance - according to the Bard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you tasted the '61? It's divine - though Paul found it - what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slightly more tannic than the '59. I prefer a smoky feeling to a fruity feeling, don't you agree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will admit she's a sexy woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This I have known for many years. You're a very lucky man. (toast)

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: PAUL (cont' d) May you make the transition from movies to literature and may your book glorify all the Shirley Temple dolls and Charlie Chaplin wristwatches that make us nostalgic for an allegedly once simpler, more charming world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit high) To the little green Heinz pickle pin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol and I are going to go dancing - we heard of a great place. Interested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be a party pooper but I just want fresh air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on - although if you're just going to sit there and obsess over where the fire exits are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Gil doesn't want to go, I'll share Paul with you. I'm very democratic. And he's a marvelous dancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's okay with you, I'd really just like a little walk and go to bed. We can do it another night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I can go, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CaNTO: 15

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not tired and I'm dying to dance. I'll just meet you back at the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take good care of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I - I - guess so В·В·В·

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 The three are having a fine time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it great we're all on holiday at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back home we just joined a marvelous tennis club and Paul says you play. Does Gil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't introduce him to tennis - Daddy's having the damndest time pressuring him to learn golf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he a good writer?     Have you read his prose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't let anybody -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he wants I'd be glad to go over his novel and critique it for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what he needs, to have it read by someone who really knows and wouldn't pull any punches. The problem is - when it comes to his writing he has no respect for anyone's opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 Gil walks street, obviously lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 Gil wanders. Eventually he is at a lovely spot. Perhaps b the river, the bridge - or somewhere else but he's just wandering lost. Finally he looks at his watch. Either by his watch or a nearby building clock, the hands move to exactly midnight. perhaps midnight chimes somewhe At precisely that moment a car happens to pull up along s him. Inside are TWO MEN and TWO WOMAN - elegant - they ha champagne and glasses and they pour from the open bottle drink happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on - get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking with French accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, we're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the wrong person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mais non, pas de tout - allez montez -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm a little drunk -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon - for god's sake - we can't sit here all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a great old peugeot. I have a friend in Beverly Hills who has the same one - he collects -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go. (dragging him in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have so many parties to go to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What parties?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Venez - la prochain        gauche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here - you need some champagne - Gil gets in.   They shut door and pull off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 rue de (tbd address) and lets hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not fair - my head is swimming from wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (refilling glass of champagne)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prenez du champagne - detendez-vous un peu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do like champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night is young - drink up, drink up, drink up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm drinking up. He drinks, befuddled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 Car pulling up at some great old street. They all get out and take him inside to a party in progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 There is a mixture of elegant plus bohemian types. In the background a MAN sits at the piano singing a Cole Porter tune. Gil looks at the revelers. A few CUTS. Music plays. Finally A WOMAN comes over to Gil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glass in hand drinking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you count Alabama as America which I do. I miss the bathtub gin. What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I - I'm a writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you write?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now I'm working on a novel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes? I'm Zelda by the way. Oh Scott - Scott come over here. Here's a writer from, where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Scott joins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott Fitzgerald, and who are you old sport?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Gil Pen - oh you two have the same names as -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott Fitzgerald and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drinking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald. The Fitzgeralds. Isn't she beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - its a coincidence.   I mean it is a funny coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a glazed look in your eye. Stunned, stupefied, anesthetized, lobotomized -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I - I - I keep thinking that man at the piano - believe it or not I recognize his face from some old sheet music - what am I talking about here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know if I put my mind to it I could be one of the great writers of musical lyrics not that I can write melodies - and I try - and then I hear the songs he writes and I realize I'll never write a great lyric and that my talent really lies in drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes but - he didn't write that song - did he? That's not possible -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of books do you write?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I - I - I - I'm - I'm working on a - exactly where am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry - Don't you know the host? Some friends have gotten together a little party for Jean Cocteau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks around, drinks it in) Hey lady, are you kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you're thinking - this is boring - I agree - I'm ready to move on - let's do Bricktop's, Scott, I'm bored, he's bored, we're all bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you say, sweetheart. See if Cole and Linda want to come with. Coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil stares open mouthed.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CAR
dialogues.text: 22 Shot of group (Gil, Cole Porter, Fitzgeralds) piled into period open top car tearing down a Parisian street. (Note can include Denise and Doug or Phil if we want)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23 The group is watching someone like Josephine Baker.     G stunned by it all. The Fitzgerald's drink a lot.

dialogues.speaker: A24
dialogues.text: Group entering cafe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 A little late night cafe, very bohemian.     Scott, Zelda Gil enter, the group having thinned out.     The Fitzgera drink a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Une bouteille de bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops at another table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greetings and salutations. You'll forgive me - I've been mixing grain and grappa В·В·В· This is Gil - Gil? Yes, Gil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil Pender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hemingway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hemingway?     Hey, is this some kind of a -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You liked my book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liked - I loved - everything you wrote -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it was a good book because it was an honest book and that's what war does to men and there's nothing fine and noble about dying in the mud unless you die gracefully and then it's not only noble but brave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernest Hemingway - this is - I -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (introduces his drinking partner)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say hello to Pender - the bulls in the ring don't frighten Belmonte - he's killed many brave ones. Fine brave bulls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure - good bulls, true bulls В·В·В·

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you smiling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drinks) In New York you can't buy this - it can only be made in a bathtub - and some of the bathtub mixtures are damn good - (to Zelda) Isn't that so? She prefers her hootch from a homemade still - more kick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hemingway) Did you read my story?   What did you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It began well - really well - then it became weak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might've known you'd hate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling you're too sensitive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You liked the story but he hates me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was some fine writing but it was not fulfilled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please old sport - you make matters extremely difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm jumpy - suddenly I don't like the atmosphere here anymore. (to Belmonte) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Para reunirse con amigos en el St. Germain ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to St. Germain.   I'm going with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zelda -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're going to stay and drink with him I'm going with the toreador.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a polite Belmonte) Get her back at a reasonable time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll drive you crazy, this woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's exciting - and she has talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This month it's writing, last month it was something else. You're a writer - you need time to write - not all this playing around - she's wasting you - because she's really a competitor - don't you agree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?   I just met -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak up for Christ's sake. I'm asking you if you think my friend is making a tragic mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually I don't know the Fitzgeralds that well -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a writer - you make observations - you were with them all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we not discuss my personal life in public?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has him on yachts, at parties, jumping into swimming pools you're wasting your talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gil) She's jealous of his gift and it's a damn fine gift. It's rare. You like his work? You can speak freely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like Mark Twain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do - very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to find Zelda. I don't like the thought of her with the Spaniard. (stumbles out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a fine writer, Fitzgerald. You box?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you writing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A novel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man who works in a nostalgia shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell's a nostalgia shop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where they sell old things - memorabilia. Does that sound terrible to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No subject is terrible if the story is true. If the prose is clean and honest and if it affirms courage and grace under pressure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you do me the biggest favor in the world - I can't even ask В·В·В·

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you read it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your novel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only about four hundred pages - if you could just give me your opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My opinion is I hate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's bad I'll hate it because I hate bad writing and if it's good I'll be envious and hate it all the more. You don't want the opinion of another writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there's no one I really trust to evaluate it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Writers are competitive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could never compete with you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too self-effacing - it's not manly. If you're a writer, declare yourself the best writer - but you're not the best as long as I'm around. Unless you want to put the gloves on and settle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - no - that's okay -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't read your novel but I'll tell you what I'll do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bring it over to Gertrude Stein. She's the only one I trust to read my work. No one discovers new talent like Gert - whether it's poetry, painting, music - She'll tell you if you have a book or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have Gertrude Stein read my novel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to get it.   It's at the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets back from Spain tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rises) I'm so thrilled - my heart is beating. I'll go home and get it - I'll give it to you - I can't tell you what this means to me. To have Gertrude Stein read my novel - thank you, thank you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm yourself - get a grip, Gil - deep breaths - been quite a night - Fitzgerald - Hemingway - the Hemingway - Papa - where do I meet him - he never said. Gil goes to return to the cafe - he can't find the door, the club facade. It's gone. We are in the present and he searches the wall of a facad where he came out but he is in despair over the fact he c find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 Next morning.   Gil and Inez probably dressing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky you didn't go last night. You'd have hated the music and the crowd - but I had fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you thinking?   You seem in a daze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I told you I was with Ernest Hemingway and Scott Fitzgerald last night, what would you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you were dreaming about? Your literary idols.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if I wasn't dreaming -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean? CaNTO: 26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I told you I spent time with Hemingway and Fitzgerald and Cole Porter -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be thinking brain tumor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I tell you Zelda Fitzgerald is exactly as we've come to know her from articles and books - she's mercurial and moody and she does not get along with Hemingway - and Scott knows Hemingway's right about it but you can see how conflicted he is because he loves her -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, right - er where's my cold cream - we should knock off the idle chatter because we're going to be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually I wanted to stay and work on my novel - it needs a little polishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can work on it later. And we can use Mom's decorator's discount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 Helen, Inez and Gil in antique store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come look at this Inez - wouldn't this be charming for a Malibu beach house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dix-huit mille.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Inez)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a steal at eighteen thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighteen thousand dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh wait, that's Euros so it's more -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's over twenty thousand dollars, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes but it's very hard to find anything like this at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's right, Gil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes but we haven't even found a house yet and I'm trying to keep expenses down so I can turn down jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get what you pay for.     Cheap is cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you love Malibu but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto seductively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever make love in a chaise like this? Imagine the possibilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er - of course when you think of it that way it does help amortize the eighteen grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't forget - we're taking you to dinner tonight at (*tbd).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto to Inez)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And after I have a terrific surprise for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   I'm not big on surprises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be. Believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at these marvelous Blackamoors. I see them in your living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 Gil and Inez arriving at the spot he was picked up by car He waits nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you taking me?   You made me rush through dinner. Dad wasn't finished with his profiteroles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going on one of the most amazing adventures of your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? And why are you carrying around your manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see - you'll see - and your jaw will drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 They're still waiting with nothing happening.       Cars no action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what it is you're carrying on about but this is not my idea of an amazing adventure. I'm exhausted from the gym and the massage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CaNTO: 29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look - you want to walk the streets and "drink in Paris by night" - go ahead. I'm in the middle of a great book Carol lent me and if I'm asleep when you get in, don't wake me. (she gets in cab)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I doing wrong? Unless she's right and I need to see a neurologist. Left the wine tasting - a little high yes - right here. The clock begins to chime midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember the river - the clock struck midnight - I - the clock struck midnight! Yes - On the dot of midnight I He looks at his watch which obviously confirms the chimes hears. The period car comes - the door opens.        We hear Hem voice: HEMINGWAY (V. o.   )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in. Gil gets in, car pulls off

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CAR
dialogues.text: 30 Only Gil and Hemingway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assignment was to take the hill. There were four of us.
HEMINGWAY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five if you counted Vincente but he had lost his hand when a grenade went off and he couldn't fight as he could when I first met him and he was young and brave and the hill was soggy from days of rain and sloped down toward a road and there were many German soldiers on the road and the idea was to aim at the first group and if our aim was true we could delay them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weren't you scared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never write well if you fear dying. Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my biggest fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's something all men before you have done and all men will do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever made love to a truly great woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fiance is very sexy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when you make love to her you feel true and beautiful passion and you at least for that moment lose your fear of death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about that - CaNTO: (2) 30

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe that love that's true and real creates a respite from death. All cowardice comes from not loving or not loving well which is the same thing and when the man who is brave and true looks death squarely in the face like some rhino hunters I know or Belmonte who is truly brave, it is because they love with sufficient passion to push death out of their minds till it returns as it does to all men and then you must make really good love again. Think about it.

dialogues.speaker: A31
dialogues.text: Shot of them arriving at Gertrude Stein's.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GERTRUDE STEIN'S PLACE
dialogues.text: 31 They enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Gil Pender. He's a young American writer. I thought you two should know each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you're here. You can help decide which of us is right and which of us is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads them into other room, introduces Gil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Gil -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pablo Picasso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ad-lib greetings. Picasso speaks French and is with beautiful girl - Adriana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just telling Pablo that this portrait doesn't capture Adriana. It has universality but no objectivity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vous ne le comprenez pas correctment. Vous ne connaissez pas Adriana mais c'est tout ce qui la represente.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No tu n'a pas raison. Look how he's done her - dripping with sexual innuendo. Carnal to the point of smoldering and yes she's beautiful but it's a subtle beauty - an implied sensuality. (to Gil)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your first impression of Adriana?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very taken)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В·В·В·В·В· Exceptionally lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belle, mais plus subtil plus implicite, Pablo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right Gertrude - of course you can see why he's lost his objectivity. (flirting with her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've made a creation of Place Pigalle, a whore with volcanic appetites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mais c'est comme elle est, si vous la connaissez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - avec vous en prive - because she's your lover - but we don't know her that way - so you make a petit bourgeoise judgment and turn her into an object of pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: 31 STEIN (cont'd) C'est plus comme une nature morte qu'on portrait. It's more like a still life than a portrait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waves her off and goes to get a drink) Je ne suis pas d'accord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Gil) And what about this book of yours I've been hearing about? (to Hemingway) Have you read it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this I leave to you. You've always been the best judge of my work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thumbing first page, she reads) "Out of the Past was the name of the store and its products consisted of memories. What was prosaic and even vulgar to one generation had been transmuted by the mere passing of years to a status at once magical and also camp. "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love it.     I'm already - hooked? Hooked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll start it tonight. But first we have something to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She collars Hemingway and they huddle to one side. Picass has busied himself at a distant spot with a drink, sulkin This leaves Gil off with Adriana to chat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did my opening lines really get to you that strongly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The past has always had a great charisma for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.     I was born too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oui, exactement. For me Belle Epoque Paris would have been perfect. The whole sensibility, the street lamps, the kiosks - the horse and carriages. And Maxims - then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You speak very good English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - and how long have you been dating Picasso? My god, did I say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - I - no, I didn't mean anything - you know - to pry В·В·В· born in Paris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was born in Bordeaux - I moved here to study fashion and - you don't want to hear this -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came here - to study with Coco Chanel - and I fell in love with Paris and also a very dark eyed, haunted, Jewish-Italian painter - and I knew Amedeo had another woman but still I couldn't resist moving into his apartment when he asked and it was a beautiful six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Modigliani? Was it Modigliani? You lived with Modigliani?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked me so I'm telling you my sad story. With Braque also there was another woman - many - and now with Pablo - I mean Pablo is married but every day it's on again, off again - I don't know how any woman can stay with him - he's so difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My god you are a whole different level of art groupie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing - I'm -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But tell me about yourself. Have you come to Paris to write because these days so many Americans feel the need to move here. Isn't Hemingway attractive? I love his writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually I'm visiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh you must stay here. It's a wonderful city for artists and writers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, I want to but it's not that simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I did fall madly in love with the start of your book so I want to hear the rest of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hemingway and Stein return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, let's all go for a drink up at Montmartre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll discuss your book as soon as I finish it. Where can I reach you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh that's okay - I'll drop by - it'll be easier for you - if that's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We run an open house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you won't come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checks watch) I only wish I could but I can't - but hopefully I'll see you again -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hemingway, Picasso and Adriana are going off - Hemingway flirtatious with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing Picasso) One of these days I plan to steal you away from this genius who's great but no Miro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 Gil returning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 Gil gets into bed with Inez. She's asleep and he lies awa thinking. He pinches himself to make sure he's awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Gil Pender - I was with Hemingway and Picasso - Pablo Picasso - Ernest Hemingway - I'm Gil Pender from Pasadena - the Cub Scouts - I failed freshman English - I'm Gil Pender and my novel is with Gertrude Stein - I once worked at The House of Pies. I'm little Gil Pender. And that girl was so lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 Gil, Inez and Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shame you two didn't come to the movies last night. We saw a wonderfully funny American film. I forget the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful but forgettable.     I've seen that picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it was moronic and infantile and lacking any wit or believability but John and I laughed in spite of ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time did you get in?     I was dead asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not late. I find these midnight strolls are very good for me creatively - without the distractions of the day - I'll probably take another long walk tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see.     Oh how about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh look at these wonderful glass figures. As they're preoccupied, Gil is caught up by a woman who p some old 78 records on an old phonograph and she's playin the Cole Porter tune Cole was playing the other night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'est jolie, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole Porter. Vous aimez - you like Cole Porter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love his music - we're very close - Cole, Linda and I. She gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very pretty and tres amusant. He listens. Inez comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil - Gil - Gil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming out if, realizing she's been talking to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should go. We're meeting Paul and Carol for a private showing at the museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the same sharp guide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a different museum and we don't need a guide. Paul's an expert on Monet.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: INEZ (cont'd) We can see all those beautiful water lilies at his home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 Paul, Carol, Inez and Gil in circular room with huge Mone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The juxtaposition of color is amazing. This man was the real father of abstract expressionism. I take that back, maybe Turner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prefer Monet. I mean I love Turner but this is overwhelming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm not mistaken it took him two years to complete this. And he worked out at Giverny - where he frequently -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say Monet used to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh. I want to hear what Paul's saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was frequently visited by Caillebotte - an artist I personally feel was underrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find Monet almost too pretty - like Renoir - sometimes it's cloying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming to Picasso's portrait of Adriana) Ah - now here's a superb Picasso.

dialogues.speaker: A36
dialogues.text: Gil is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm not mistaken he painted this marvelous portrait of his French mistress Madeline Brissou in the twenties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er - I have to differ with you on this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil pay attention and you'll learn something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm not mistaken this was a failed attempt to capture a young French girl named Adriana - from Bordeaux - if my art history serves me - came to Paris to study costume design for the theatre. Believe she had a brief affair with Modigliani - then Braque - that's where Pablo met her - er Picasso. You'd never know it from this portrait but she's quite subtly beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you been smoking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'd hardly call the picture superb. It's more of a petit bourgeoise statement of how Pablo er Picasso sees her, saw her - he's distracted by the fact she was a volcano in the sack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 John, Helen and Inez finishing fancy dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too rich for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did Gil run off to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work - he likes to walk around Paris - the way the city is all lit up at night allegedly inspires him - It's okay. Paul and I are going dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Carol?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In bed with a bad oyster. (rising) See you later. Thanks for dinner Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does Gil go every night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard her. He walks and gets ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I see what he earns but sometimes I think he's got a part missing. And I didn't like his remark about tea party Republicans. They're decent people who want to take back the country - they're not crypto-fascist, airhead zombies. Did you hear him say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevertheless I hardly think your idea of having him followed is practical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? I'd like to know where he goes every night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we know one thing - he doesn't go dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 Gil dancing with a woman at Fitzgerald's party.    He sto finally and Adriana wanders over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello again? How nice you're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was at Gertrude Stein's - she's almost finished with my novel. And the Fitzgeralds invited me over and said you'd be here - you and Pablo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pablo's home - we had a bit of a quarrel. But you looked like you were having fun dancing with Djuna Barnes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was Djuna Barnes?   No wonder she wanted to lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't this a wonderful place to throw a party - only the Fitzgeralds would think of it. Look - this is from the turn of the century. Everything was so beautiful then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hemingway coming over now.    He squeezes Adriana playful flirtatious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't this little Parisienne dream a movable feast? Mark my words - I'm going to steal you from that fugitive from Malaga one way or the other.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: 37 HEMINGWAY (cont'd) (referring to his companion of the moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between Belmonte and myself - which of us would you choose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vous etes tous deux tres impressionants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he has more courage. He faces death more directly and more often and if you chose him I would be disappointed but understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Por desgracia para ambos ella ha elegido Pablo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she's chosen Picasso - But Pablo thinks women are only to paint or sleep with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think women are the equal of men in courage. Have you ever shot a charging lion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever hunted? (to Gil)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only for bargains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hemingway)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: venga - tomemos otra copa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Adriana)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to maybe take a walk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 Gil and Adriana walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope it was nothing serious with you and Pablo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's moody and possessive.   Artists are all like children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand why they all want to paint you - you're so damn interesting to look at in a lovely way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're interesting in a lost way. Tell me more about your book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about my book. I want to enjoy Paris by night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep forgetting, you're only a tourist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's putting it mildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 Adriana is showing him around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can never decide whether Paris is more beautiful by day or by night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no book or painting, or symphony or sculpture that can rival a great city. All these streets and boulevards as a special art form.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: 39 GIL (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you think in the cold, violent, meaningless universe Paris exists - these lights - I mean nothing's happening on Jupiter or Neptune or out beyond - but from way out in space you can see these lights in the whole dark void - the cafes, people drinking and dancing - I mean for all we know this town is the hottest spot in the entire universe -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vous avez l'ame d'un poete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very kind. I would not call my babbling poetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 Gil and Adriana are here with the street lined with prostitutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See anything you like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ashamed to admit I'm attracted to all of them. I like cheap-sexy. I know it's shallow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was in Catholic school, one weekend, my roommate and I paid one of the girls of Pigalle to come teach us all her tricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's the most interesting thing I've ever heard in my life - I'd like to think about that for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 Gil and Adriana walking by the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love that the main character in your book sells memories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he believes in his soul that progress is not automatically for the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Often quite the opposite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say - is that who I think it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is she doing here? And why is she staring into the river. They see a distraught woman contemplating jumping into th river. Upon running to her, it's Zelda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh gosh!   My god - what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please leave me alone.   I don't want to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It all became clear to me tonight. Scott and that beautiful Countess - it was so obvious they were whispering about me and the more they drank the more he fell in love with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott loves only you. I can tell you with absolute certainty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's tired of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you're wrong. I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?   How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me.      I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you just met us. How can you know anything. My skin hurts. I hate the way I look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this. (pill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Valium - it'll calm you down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You carry medicine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only since Inez and I became engaged. I've had these anxiety attacks - I'm sure after the wedding they'll subside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never heard of Valium.   What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er - it's the pill of the future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But pills wear off - and then it all comes back. No, I won't kill myself. I'll write and I'll write more passionately than Scott. I'll work harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He loves you. He's not with that woman. She's already on her way back to Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try and score some more for you. And I have some Xanax at the hotel - it's another one you'll like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, we'll find a taxi. We'll see you home - things will be better in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never said you were getting married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - I - I mean it's in the future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well good luck with your book and your wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd like Inez - she has a sharp sense of humor - and she's sexy - not that we agree on everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the important things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually the small things - the important things we don't - she'd like to live in Malibu and that I'd work in Hollywood - but I will say we both like - er - er Indian food - not all Indian food - pita bread - we both like pita bread -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) I should go. Pablo will be missing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll walk you home -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO, no В·В·В· Finish your drink.      I live just around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I wouldn't think -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd prefer to be by myself for awhile. Thank you for this evening. And she goes. He's stressed, thinks. Presently Salvador D comes to table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We met earlier tonight.    At the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - I remember -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dali - si? Dali! Dali!      Une bouteille de vin rouge I waiter scurries for one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like the shape of the rhinoceros?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rhinoceros?    I never thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I paint rhinoceros. I paint you - sad eyes - big lips - melting over hot sand - with one tear - yes - and in your tear - Christ's face. And rhinoceros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure I look sad. I'm in a very perplexing situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is in perplexing situation - to be or not to be - this is ultimate perplexing question - you agree? Ah - here they are -

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: 43 Bufiuel, Man Ray enter and the table enlarges as they sit Dali introduces them to Gil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My god, I own a surrealist print - only a print by Magritte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pender - Pen-der - Pen-derrr - and I am Da-li. Pender is in perplexing situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds so crazy when I say it and you'll think I'm drunk but I've got to tell someone I'm from a different time - a whole other era - the future - and I pass from the two thousandth millennium to here - a car picks me up - I slide through time -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly correct - you inhabit two worlds - so far I see nothing strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you're sur-realists - but I'm a normal guy - See, in one life I'm engaged to marry a woman I love - at least I think I love her. Christ, I'm supposed to love her if I'm marrying her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love - the word love - love - the word love - same as the word rhinoceros - the rhinoceros makes love by mounting the female - but is there difference in beauty between two rhinoceroses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there is nothing more sur-real than the human heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Past is also present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a dream - which is fine for you because you guys dabble in dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is another woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adriana is her name. And I felt drawn to her - but it wouldn't matter - men much greater than me, profound artists - she's drawn to geniuses - and they to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you with Christ - he is smiling while you are crucified on the heavy wooden cross of self- doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course my biggest problem is reality. BuNuEL Reality is nothing more than a dream - we all exist in the dream of a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was born in the wrong time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time is all the mind. Time melts - the watches melt - the hands of the clock melt В·В·В·

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man in love with a woman from a different era. I see a photograph. BuNuEL I see a movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see an insurmountable problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see - a rhinoceros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44 Next morning.   Room service breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get much work done last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er - some - yes - I'm beginning to think my book may be too realistic - that I've missed some chances to let my imagination run wild and not be so damn logical В·В·В·

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we be getting dressed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mere - you always look great in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she does)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to work. I'm working like a demon but I can't resist you half dressed like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul says we have to see the countryside. He's taking us for lunch at this beautiful little inn. I know you like making love in the morning but I find it much sexier late afternoon - just before we go out to dinner. Except I always have to explain to my parents why your cheeks look radiant. Hey- I'm not going to force you. I know you're hot on your writing. I'll be happy when you finish this book and move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 Gil is near The Kiss.     He has tracked down the guide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello - Bonjour - I'd like to ask you a question about Rodin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He loved his wife, he also loved his mistress - is it really possible to be in love with two women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He loved both in different ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God it's so French. Er - you remember me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. Qui - you were with the group, the pedantic gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, pedantic - perfect word. You're very observant. I need some advice. I'd like a woman's take. A French woman - an observant French woman. I met some woman that I very quickly became smitten with. Smitten?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm engaged to be married. I know Rodin had a wife and a mistress but I'm American - we can't handle that - we're monogamous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're engaged and you met a new woman -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Her name's Adriana. Right now she's living with Picas-- with a Spaniard - er he paints - fairly well. В·В·

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - and does she love him?   Or you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love him or me? Well I hardly think, me. But we've just met. See, another very gifted man flirts with her, a writer. All these geniuses fall in love with her. And what am I? And then of course there's another big problem. I can't exactly explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know whether to call it an age difference - or a problem of geography - I'm so messed up. I'm not Hemingway, I'm not Picasso, I'm not Rodin. I'm just a guy who was born too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47 John walks down a street and enters a building. As he goe up the stairs we learn it is the office of a private detective agency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 John and M. DuBois, the head detective.     M. Tisserant, second is present too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's his photo. I want to know where he goes each night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your suspicion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's engaged to my daughter - to marry and I want to be certain she's making a wise decision. Naturally discretion is paramount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've come to the right place, monsieur. Monsieur Tisserant - will personally keep track of the gentleman and report back on his whereabouts at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 Gil getting into the car as usual at the same spot at midnight. Another man is in there. Tisserant is observing from his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gets in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for stopping.   Gil Pender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Eliot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Eliot? Tom - Stearns - T.S. Eliot? T.S. Eliot? SHOT of Gil entering car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm stunned, stunned - Prufrock - my mantra - As the car pulls off, we hear Gil speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I tell you where I come from they measure out their lives in coke spoons.
Picasso present - dour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Pender - I'll get to your book in a moment. I finished it. We're just in the middle of a little personal crisis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to intrude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's no secret. Adriana has left Pablo and has flown to Africa with Ernest Hemingway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sabia que tenia una obsesi6n con este fanforr6n. Sobre esto discutimos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Estoy seguro que regresara muy devoto. (English to Gil)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He took her hunting kudu but she'll be back to him - the sound of hyenas every night when you're trying to sleep in a tent gets on your nerves pretty quickly. Mt. Kilimanjaro is not Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're on Mt. Kilimanjaro?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now about your book. Very unusual indeed. In a way it's almost science fiction - fiction with all the futuristic devices - television sets, supersonic flight - and yet it's not typical science fiction - it's unique.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: 51 STEIN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevertheless you have to get rid of all that technology - what's good about your book are the characters - the human questions - love - mortality - nobody cares about the technology, they care about the human heart. We all fear death and question our place in the universe. Unfortunately your book lapses into easy pessimism. I was having this conversation with Giacometti the other day - he's such a gloom monger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, those sculptures -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the artist's job not to succumb to despair but to find an antidote to the emptiness of existence. I find your voice clear and lively - don't be such a defeatist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 Inez, her mother and father loading into car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Gil to bring a suit because tomorrow night we'll be dining formal. Where's Gil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot to tell you. Gil is not going with us to Mont St. Michel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?   I don't understand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He writes, he rewrites, he rewrites his rewrites. He says Picasso never left his studio.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: 53 INEZ (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, Gil, you have absolutely nothing in common with Picasso В·В·В· He just looks at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he's going to miss a great weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55 Gil browsing.   He listens to the old phonograph recordin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any Cole Porter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes - I remember - he was your friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was kidding you realize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did realize. You're a bit young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised you're so familiar with his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wrote many songs about Paris - very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - he was in love with your hometown. You're a Parisiene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oui monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dix-huit euro.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: 55 He pays.   Takes album.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 Gil at a place that has a bin of various old books more pretty than great - the kind people buy for the binding o plates. He picks up a pretty bound but totally wrecked book in th inside. It is slim, leather, torn up. He reads the title page in hand writing.     It reads: diary belongs to Adriana Dupree."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to customer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you translate this?   Speak English? customer shrugs.   Moves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 Gil with Museum Guide.    She's translating the diary int English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Paris exists and anyone could choose to live anywhere else in the world will always be a mystery to me. Turns pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner with Pablo and Henri Matisse. Pablo is the greater artist although Matisse is the greater painter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris in the summer - what it must have been like to sit opposite one's lover at Maxim's in it's heyday. Pages are torn and text cuts off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am in love with an American writer I just met named Gil Pender. His eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That immediate magic one hears about happened to me. I know that both Picasso and Hemingway are in love with me but for whatever inexplicable reasons the heart has, I am drawn to Gil. Perhaps because he seems naive and unassuming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As always in this sad life he is about to marry a woman named Inez.
