I had a dream where he came to me and brought me a little gift - earrings they were - and we made love. perhaps it is just as well I accept Hemingway's offer to go to Africa. Life with Pablo is too full of conflict and I am suffocating under his genius. Why I need to go from one brilliant man to another is my weakness. Gil is different, perhaps not a genius but not moody and selfish like Pablo or Amedeo was. I think a trip to Africa with Hemingway would help get these feelings for Gil off my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finished reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a little complicated to explain. Thanks for translating -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The writer clearly has feelings for this man Gil. That's your name, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finds him no genius - naive and unassuming - that's not exactly dazzling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To some women naivete is   endearing. And she's romantic. She    dreams of Belle Epoque Paris and a   gift of earrings and making love   with this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil stares, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 Gil is sprucing up. He douses himself with aftershave, checks clock. It's eleven PM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Eleven - let's see - where the hell am I going to get earrings at this hour? (thinks) I must improvise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to Inez's jewelry box and picks out art nouveau earrings he knows Adriana would like. He grabs a box and gift wraps it quickly. Maybe it comes in a blue velvet box and he finds some col paper. Gil writes card: To Adriana with love. He crosses it out - To Adriana avec amour. He gives a final check to himself and opens door to leave running smack into Inez and both her parents, home from t trip prematurely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohmigodl   What are you doing back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy got chest pains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it's indigestion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we can't take a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy had an angioplasty three years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They put a balloon in me.    Big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - I want the hotel doctor - suite 818. (she trails off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you so dressed up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?   No - I was just writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You dress and put on cologne to write?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took a break and showered. I think better in the shower. All those positive ions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were halfway to Mont. St. Michele and Daddy started to look pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We turned right around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - sure - is there anything I can get you, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I'm sure it's the beef bourguignon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this. (picking up gift)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabs it from her) It's nothing - nothing -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?     It's a present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - yes В·В·В· it is. Because it's gift wrapped В·В·В· but er - you're not supposed to see that - it's a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got me something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing great - from the flea market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me open it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No - not now В·В·В· I got it for - I mean to give it to you at a special dinner - just leave it В·В·В·

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm dying of curiosity. If it's jewelry I hope it's my taste - not like the moonstone necklace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't like the moonstones? They're understated yet elegant - (to Helen) Don't you always say that, ha, ha .В·.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheap is cheap is what I always say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never saw the necklace he got me. I've never actually worn it. You'll see why immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opens her jewelry box, holds up moonstones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd like their simplicity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just it, they're too simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey - where are my art nouveau earrings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You probably didn't pack them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've worn them here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you lost them.     They probably dropped off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of them?     My ears are pierced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you to keep everything in the hotel safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it was the maid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always the maid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember seeing them there this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would report the theft right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet it was that maid. She was so snotty yesterday about turning out the beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee I wouldn't jump to any conclusions. I mean an accusation of theft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (phone) I want to report a theft. I'd like the house detective to please come to room 818.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hangs up) I didn't like that maid from the first day, didn't I say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Door rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The maid was very sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening door, doctor is there) Right. Take the side of the help as usual. That's why Dad calls you a Communist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Dr. Gerard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in - he's right there В·В·В·

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's had an angioplasty.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: 59 Amidst the ad-lib moment, Gil has managed to secure a pri spot and has swiped the box. He's torn it open and removi earrings, runs into the room with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! Look! Are these what you're missing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you find them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right out on the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in the bathroom, I didn't see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you're under stress В·В·В·

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the hell would they be in the bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you thought you put them away and left them out or dropped them, and the maid found them and left them out where you could see them easily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't drop them or leave them out ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The main thing is they're not stolen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to send you for some tests but I think that you are right and this is only indigestion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See. Incidentally, it was very nice of you to come over so late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - my god, is it midnight already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil is disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 Gil is buying earrings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 He is behind the wheel of his car observing. Car stops - picks up Gil, pulls off. Tisserant pulls off to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Matisse) C'est l'un de vos meilleurs jusqu'a present. Je parlai a Leo. Je pense qu'il souhaite l'acheter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matisse is delighted, goes about his business there as sh turns to Gil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just telling Matisse we want to buy one of his new pictures for our personal collection. Five hundred francs seems fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred francs? For a Matisse? (half to himself)

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: 63 GIL (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, why don't I pick up half a dozen? I could clean up - but how's all this possible - I should have paid more attention in my physics class В·В·В·

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh er - I brought a rewrite of the first few chapters of my book and was hoping you would tell me if you thought I was on the right track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er - have you heard from Hemingway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, they've been back for days. The trip didn't work out. I knew they wouldn't hit it off. That's over. with Picasso too. She's at Deyrolles - by herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By herself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On of those surrealist painters is getting married and they did it up there. She'll be glad to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 Wedding in progress.    Informal, non-traditional wedding artist type guests. Gil finds Adriana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to find you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just say as a writer I see into women's souls and I sense that you have very complicated feelings towards me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're going to be married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not so sure about anything anymore - can we just go where it's quiet? They are almost out the door when they run into Luis Bufi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Bufiuel, I had a nice idea for a movie for you. BuNuEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of people are at a formal dinner party and after dinner when they try to leave the room, they can't. BuNuEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just can't seem to exit the door. BuNuEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And because they're all forced to stay together the veneer of civilization quickly comes off them and they behave as who they really are - animals. BuNuEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't get it - why don't they just walk out of the room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just think about it - that's all I'm saying - maybe one day you'll be shaving and it'll tickle your fancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go off as Bufiuel gets in last line. BuNuEL I don't understand - what's holding them in the room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 Gil and Adriana at romantic locale.     He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know but I do know that for a brief moment, when I was doing it, I felt - immortal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But - you look so sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because life is too mysterious for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the time we live in. Everything moves so fast - life is noisy and complicated - not like the Belle Epoque. In those years Paris lived only for beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always been a logical person. I never took chances - did anything crazy - like move here when I first came or take a shot at being a real writer, not a Hollywood hired hand - but I feel like letting everything go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil gives her earrings. CaNTO: 65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How remarkable - they're beautiful. A horse and carriage pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur, mademoiselle - on y vas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montez. On y vas.      Nous allons etre en retard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? They get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To drink champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 They pull up at Maxims. People from the Belle Epoque ente and exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All those pictures I've seen of Belle Epoque Paris. We're herel -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what it is about this city but I must write a thank you note to the chamber of commerce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 Inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome - and oh what marvelous outfits. So avant garde - please have some champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe this is happening to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 Gil and Adriana are dancing romantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never want to go back to the present. Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The present - Yes, the present always seems worse than the past but it can't be - to always think this generation is stupider and coarser than the last - and yet - here we are at Maxims tonight and yes, it's fabulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I know just where I want to go after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 The girls dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 Gil and Adriana sit and hold hands.   Dance ends and girl off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to waiter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Encore du vin. Le meme chose. (to Gil)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't this something. Lookl Look I She points out Lautrec sketching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pablo worships him. I have to say hello. Come with me, I'm nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shouldn't bother him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we know he's a lonely man В·В·В· he longs for company. They go over.   She speaks to Lautrec.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're both great admirers of your work. Nous sommes tout les deux de grands admirateurs de votre travail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merci madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pouvons nous vous offrir un verre?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J'en serai enchante mademoiselle. Prenez un siege je vous en prie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's asking us to sit down with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This much French I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Etes vous Americain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm American. Oui -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Je l'ai devine a votre accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nous aimons, tous les vos dessins et peintures, en realite tout ce que vous faites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I love your pictures too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (welcomes two new men to table) Oh - puis-je vous presenter mes amis В·В·В· Monsieur Degas and Monsieur Gauguin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohmigoodness - hello - enchante - (ad-lib hellos best they can) (to Gil) Isn't this thrilling? You see the sketch he's made? Nobody can draw like that today - not Pablo, not Matisse -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see fine drawing, Lautrec style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parlez Anglais?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to Gauguin) 11 parle un petit peut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I speak well - je parle tres bien.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scornfully over Gauguin's boasting) Ah-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Degas and I were just talking about how - cette generation est depourvue de sens et mangue d'imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says they find this generation sterile and empty -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La Renaissance est beaucoup mieux - better to have lived during the Renaissance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - this is the Golden Age - L'Age D'or.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pas do tout - la Renaissance - c'etait mieux - leur vetements sont tres, tres modernes, tres originaux.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says your clothes are very modern and original.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er - yes - Monsieur Lauren - Ralph. (to Gauguin) Shouldn't you be in Tahiti?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I? What? Yes - I live on the island - a much better life than here - better there - but then I miss Paris - up and back - Qu'est que vous faites dans la vie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I do? Je suis etudiante. En haute couture - fashion designer but studying -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah ga compte pour les vetements outrageux.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vous devriez la presenter a Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants Degas to have you meet his friend Richard.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: 70 GAUGUIN ( cont ' d) He's looking for someone to do costumes for the ballet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ballet costumes - my god - I don't live here. I mean I do but I don't. Je n'habite pas ici.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't get into too many details with them. Let's just leave it that we're temporarily passing through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gil) Can I speak with you a minute? (to table) Permettez-moi de m'absenter un instant. (she gets him off) Let's never go back to the twenties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should stay here - it's the start of the Belle Epoque - this is the greatest, most beautiful era Paris has ever known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I love the Jazz Age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The twenties are full of strife and uncertainty. But think of it, Gil - the two of us - in a lovely art nouveau home - I'll work in the fashion world - I love the styles - you can write В·В·В· it's the age of Debussy and Guimard. Maybe you can meet Balzac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what happened to the twenties and the Charleston and Cole Porter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the present, it's dull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the present for me - I'm from 2010.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dropped in on you just the way we dropped in on the 1890's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to escape my present just like you wanted to escape yours. To a golden age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely you don't think the twenties are a golden age?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To me they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm from the twenties and I'm tellin~ you the golden age is the Belle Epoque.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes but don't you see - to these guys the golden age was the Renaissance. They'd all trade the Belle Epoque to paint alongside Michelangelo or Titian. And those guys probably imagine life was better when Kubla Khan was around. I'm having an insight. A minor one but that accounts for the anxiety of my dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What dream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night I dreamed I ran out of zithromax - and then I went to the dentist and there was no novacaine - these people have no antibiotics -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And even in the twenties - no dishwashers - no 911 if your appendix bursts - no "movies on demand" В·

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if we love each other what does it matter when we live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if you stay here and this becomes your present, sooner or later you'll imagine another time was really the golden time. And so will I - I'm beginning to see why it can't work, Adriana. The present has a hold on you because it's your present and while there's never any progress in the most important things, you get to appreciate - what little progress is made - the internet - Pepto- Bismol. The present is always going to seem unsatisfying because life itself is unsatisfying - that's why Gauguin goes back and forth between Paris and Tahiti, searching - it's my job as a writer to try and come up with reasons why despite life being tragic and unsatisfying, it's still worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the problem with writers - you're all so full of words - but I'm more emotional. I'm going to stay and live in Paris' most glorious time. You made a choice to leave Paris once and you regretted it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that one I regretted but it was a real choice and I made the wrong one. This is a choice between accepting reality or surreal insanity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So finally you do love Inez more than me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - I love you - but this way lies madness - and if I'm ever going to write anything worthwhile I've got to get rid of my illusions and that I'd be happier in the past is one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Gil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye Adriana.     Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss, she turns and goes to the table of artists.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GERTRUDE STEIN'S PLACE
dialogues.text: 71 Gil being admitted to the Stein home.          He is full

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah - Pender - I read your rewrite. Yes В·В·В· you're nicely on the right track. You've understood me clearly. If the rest of the book reads as well when you're done you'll have something of value.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking it back) Thank you. I can't tell you how much this means to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hemingway who read your chapters and agrees it's going to be a fine book did have one plot suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hemingway read it?    What was his suggestion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CaNTO: 71

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finds it hard to believe the protagonist doesn't see his fiancee is having an affair that's going on right before his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other character - the pedantic one -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called denial. Thanks again. (to passing poet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Ezra Pound right? T.S. Eliot says you owe him forty francs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 Gil back in present in mid-argument with Inez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy - Paul and me? Where did you get such an insane notion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Ernest Hemingway. He thought it out and it makes perfect sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil, your brain tumor's acting up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing crazy about Ernest Hemingway or Gertrude Stein or Fitzgerald or Salvador Dali -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing except they've all been dead for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was William Faulkner who said, the past is not dead.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: GIL (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, it's not even past. Actually I ran into Bill Faulkner at a party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a raving lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'm too trusting. I'm jealous and also trusting - cognitive dissonance, Scott Fitzgerald speaks of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it Inez - you can fool me but not Hemingway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ I'm dealing with a madman - okay - Paul and I had a few nights alone. We danced, we drank - you were always working - he's very attractive, he spoke to me in French - the whole mystique of this corny city got to me - it's over. We can put this all in perspective at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm staying here. It's not the romantic fling. Paris is Paris. It's that I'm not in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot has happened    to me since we got here. I won't     begin to bore you - but - I know    what that feeling of love is    and it's not us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you met someone else?      All those late night walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was attracted to another woman but it was the whole deal - meeting Gertrude Stein and Hemingway and Dali and Scott and Zelda -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, you better listen to yourself. You're a psycho. You don't know what you're doing. You see everything here through magical colored glasses. You're a California film writer with a house in Beverly Hills with two Mercedes'. You're not some kind of twenties expatriate novelist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her parents enter from the adjoining suite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?       We can hear every word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm not happy I'll move back. But right now I'm going to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With who? All your crazy hallucinatory friends? Mother was right about you - there's a part missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: said that first. ~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone who's protagonist makes a living selling old cap pistols and Joan Crawford cut out books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're better off without me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Walk the streets - gush over the Parisian light and the rooftops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye Inez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a private detective follow him - I knew he was up to no good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy you didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. He saw him get into a car at midnight each night and he followed close behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. The detective agency says the detective is missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 Detective Tisserant is in a period room with two stunned period occupants. They all speak French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A qui ai-je l'honneur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Je me suis perdu - J'ai pas du tourner au bon endroit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guardes!   Guardes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qu'on lui coupe la tete!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 Gil walking at night. He sees someone approaching and realizes it is the girl from the Flea Market, Gabrielle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I know you - the girl at the flea market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes - yes - the Cole Porter one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm returning from dinner with my girlfriends. I live near here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle, - I'm Gil - I just moved to Paris this week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I'm sure you'll love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I walk along with you or can I buy you a coffee? Oh god, it's starting to rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. I don't mind getting wet. Paris is the most beautiful in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh what a thing to say.     I couldn't agree more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just thought about you the other day because my boss got in a whole album of Cole Porter songs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey what are those bells?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Midnight - right - right - pretty name. FADE OUT as they walk off together in the rain.
